rounds.comments: (Ken: Not that big a surprise on Jeopardy! But, you know, a little surprise.)

clues.text: This title guy said, "Yond Cassius has a lean and hungry look... such men are dangerous"; he should have listened to his instincts
The title of this play is fulfilled in Act V, scene 3, when Helena finally gets her Bertram
It took Shakespeare 3 plays to tell the story of this king from his boyhood to his murder in the Tower
Somewhat ironically, Autolycus sings about daffodils, "the sweet o' the year" & "summer songs" in this play
Shakespeare didn't print his plays but did shepherd some of his poems through printing, including this one about 2 mythical beauties
Casamigos Añejo & Don Julio Blanco are bottles of this
Queen Victoria adorns the label of this brand's Sapphire gin
The word "whiskey" comes from the Gaelic for "water of life", a translation of this Latin phrase
One ingredient in Aperol is this tart root also known as the pieplant
This Mexican liqueur brand uses arabica coffee beans & rum
The removal of 4 dams on the Klamath River has cut hydro power a bit but allowed these fish to return to their historic habitat
OPEC's 1973 ban on sales to the U.S., then heavily dependent on foreign oil, is known as this word from the Spanish
This word is found in the names of 3 now-decommissioned nuclear power plants, following Vermont, Maine & of course Connecticut
A turning point in empowering U.S. labor was a 1902 strike of this state's anthracite miners, driving up prices
Rapid clicking when you try to start your car is a sign of cold cranking, a problem with this item
Rising from the Nevada desert in 2008, this band has had Top 10 hits with songs like "Demons" & "Radioactive"
This word that follows Uther in the name of King Arthur's father is a title for ancient British chiefs
This book's title character is "Armansky's star researcher... a pale, anorexic young woman who had hair as short as a fuse"
Duanwu Jie in Chinese, this festive holiday features aquatic races, rice dumplings & rituals to ward off evil
This warning is not really found on old maps but really is found (in Latin) on a globe circa 1510
Staying on brand in 1581, he murdered his heir & namesake; Russia's Time of Troubles lay ahead
Carlos I of this nation & his son were slain in 1908; another son, Manuel II, would take over, but by 1910 a republic was born
This heir, a valuable pawn after his mom & dad got the guillotine in 1793, was determined to have died in a prison
Archduke Karl Ludwig's death made Franz Ferdinand next up for the Austro-Hungarians, but Franz would die in this city
Cleopatra's son with a famous dad, he was king of Egypt for a while but larger ambitions saw his downfall in Alexandria
Symbol Mg, this element that's essential to life might help with sleep issues & prevent migraines
27.7% of the Earth's crust is made up of this element that's used in computer chips
Iron combines with oxygen to make ferric oxide, aka this mineral named for its blood red color
The Og of elements is oganesson--though we don't know for sure it's a gas, it's part of group 18, this septet
You may have to drink this whitish element in liquid form for imaging of your GI tract
No. 40 of U.S. vice presidents, he was on 2 national championship-winning college football teams
There's always a spot on our chart for the "Nine" who bravely desegregated Central High School in this city in 1957
This foreigner was "Top '40" as Henry VIII's queen in 1540--from a tough wedding night in January to July
Alphabetically, it tops the chart of locations for the 7 Wonders of the Ancient World
This "numeric band" that included Yao Wenyuan dropped off the chart hard after Mao left the stage for good in 1976
Seen in some workplaces, it's discrimination based on how old someone is
It's the art or sport of climbing high mountains & not necessarily the ones that gave it its name
Sounds deadly, but it's the belief that events in life are predetermined & people are powerless to change them
Author Jean-Paul Sartre was a leader of this literary & philosophical movement
This movement in the arts & literature that began in the late 1700s emphasized passion, emotion & imagination
A word for informers; they proverbially "get stitches"
Named for a cartoon spirit, it's a ghosting technique where the ghoster & ghostee stop texting but in a friendly way
These 4 words spell out a phrase for your soulmate; some say the acronym is pronounced "lom-el"
Like "Black '47", it's a movie with a Western feel set in Ireland, not a spaghetti Western but...
Also called a "man on the street" interview, these 2 3-letter words are shortened Latin for "voice of the people"
This river abruptly changed course on March 7, 1876, leaving Reverie, Tennessee on the Arkansas side
With Cameroon on its western border & South Sudan on the east, it's right in the middle of the continent
Now a tourist attraction, the demilitarized zone separating these 2 countries was officially abolished in 1976
The Mexican state of Quintana Roo has a southern border with Belize & a NW one with this state that shares a name with the whole area
This country sits on France's northeast border, sandwiched between Belgium & Germany
"Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall"

Describing her historic 1983 space flight:
"That was definitely an E ticket"
On her nomination to the Supreme Court: "This is a momentous day in my life and the life of my family"
A champion of human rights: "Our only protection is to boycott the grapes"
At the 1988 Democratic National Convention: "We are all precious in God's sight--the real rainbow coalition"
The title of this 1880 novel refers to siblings Dmitry, Ivan & Alyosha
Hopelessness is the theme of the 1899 Chekhov drama named for this title character who realizes he's wasted his life
Solzhenitsyn gave an account of his 8 years in Soviet prison camps in this work & used its proceeds to help persecuted folks
This author of "Doctor Zhivago" won & accepted the Nobel Prize, but then was forced to decline by the Soviets
His short story "The Overcoat" is considered one of the foundations of Russian realism

rounds.text: After studying business in Chicago in the 1920s, this man obsessed with Sherlock Holmes was an investigator for a credit company
